TopicTitle: NASA Article - The Tyranny of the Rocket Equation

Articles.Content:
Found this on Reddit. Thought it would be enjoyed here as well.

http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/expeditions/expedition30/tryanny.html
And now having finished it, I realize I never considered the preantepenultimate paragraph as one possible explanation for the Fermi paradox.

I like this quote from that article:

And physics dictates that paying a penny less than the full cost will result in Earth repossessing your spacecraft in a not so gentle way.

Also, that "useful mass" comparison between a soda can and the Space Shuttle's external tank really puts things into perspective when you think of the difference in weight between a full soda can and an empty one.

"The rocket equation contains three variables. Given any two of these, the third becomes cast in stone. Hope, wishing, or tantrums cannot alter this result."

I disagree. A sufficiently passionate tantrum can alter anything.

And now having finished it, I realize I never considered the preantepenultimate paragraph as one possible explanation for the Fermi paradox.

Not really, the rocket equation is a nightmare, but there is also always a way to make a non rocket launch system... there is plenty of those, at least in idea forms to go around.
i like how this article sounds like it was written by a redneck.

i like how this article sounds like it was written by a redneck.

I blame the "barn dance" simile
there was at least one rodeo reference too.
